question: Question_07_(a)
statement:
The length of time in minutes it takes students to solve a certain
mathematics problem (on probability) is a continuous random variable
whose probability density function is

\begin{align*}f(x) = \begin{cases} k\cos(x/10)\sin^2(x/10), & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 5\pi, \\
0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{align*}

(a) Find the value of the positive constant $k$.
sols:
First, note that \emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10) $\geq$ 0 and
\emph{sin}(\emph{x}/10) $\geq$ 0 for any 0 $\leq$ x $\leq$ 5$\pi$. Hence we
need \emph{k} $\geq$ 0 as well.

To satisfy the second condition we require

\begin{align*}1 = \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = \int_0^{5\pi} k\cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) \sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx.\end{align*}

The integral can easily be solved using the substitution \emph{u} =
\emph{sin}(\emph{x}/10), \emph{du} = 1/10 \emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10), so
that \emph{u}(0) = 0 and \emph{u}(5$\pi$) = \emph{sin}($\pi$/2) = 1. Hence we
need to choose \emph{k} such that

\begin{align*}
1 &= \int_0^{5\pi} k\cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) \sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^1 10ku^2\,du \\
&= \left.\frac{10ku^3}3\right|_0^1 \\
&= \frac{10}3 k\end{align*}

Hence we choose''' \emph{k} = 3/10. '''
hints:
For $f$ to be a probability density function it needs to satisfy two
conditions:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f$(x) $\geq$ 0 for all \emph{x},
\item
  $\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1.$
\end{itemize}

Choose \emph{k} such that both conditions are fulfilled.
